posts.title: I feel like hacker is not such an unrelated term like rockstar or ninja are.

virtuals.snippet: To me, a hacker is an enthusiastic and skillful developer.
virtuals.emailSnippet: To me, a hacker is an enthusiastic and skillful developer. For example, I would consider myself a ‘civic hacker’ because I enjoy (and got quite good at) building applications that help the community and local government.

paragraphs.name: d39b
paragraphs.text: I feel like hacker is not such an unrelated term like rockstar or ninja are. To me, a hacker is an enthusiastic and skillful developer. For example, I would consider myself a ‘civic hacker’ because I enjoy (and got quite good at) building applications that help the community and local government.

posts.title: How to Write an Angular 2 Component

virtuals.snippet: An explanation of Angular Docs for everyone
virtuals.subtitle: An explanation of Angular Docs for everyone
virtuals.emailSnippet: The Angular team introduced quite a few changes in version 2 of the framework, and components are one of the important ones. If you are familiar with Angular 1 applications, components are actually a form of directives that have been extended with template-oriented features. In addition, components are optimized for better performance and simpler configuration than a directive since it doesn’t support all its features.

paragraphs.name: previewTitle
paragraphs.text: How to Write an Angular 2 Component

posts.title: Three easy ways to deploy an Angular app for free

virtuals.snippet: Using Github pages, Amazon S3 bucket, and Heroku
virtuals.subtitle: Using Github pages, Amazon S3 bucket, and Heroku
virtuals.emailSnippet: Making an AngularJS application can be a lot of fun and a great way to experiment with front-end frameworks. One downside is that you can’t see your project deployed on the web unless you are using a framework on the back-end / server-side such as Meteor, NodeJS, Rails, etc. or you are already paying for a server instance. Luckily for us, there are many ways to get around this and I’ll show you three super-easy ways to get your set of “static” (technically you are only hosting one index page…

Using Github pages, Amazon S3 bucket, and Heroku

posts.title: How to make your first video game

virtuals.subtitle: A brief overview of Unity 3D
virtuals.emailSnippet: Last night, me and 9 (web) developers were challenged to take on a new technology, learn it in a 24 hour period, and present it to the group. It could be anything that had a practical value to our career. Some of the topics chosen included Node.js, Socket.io, Redis, Meteor.js, and D3.js data visualization. Me, being the video-game hobbyist that I am, opted for picking up Unity 3D and deploying a game as a web application.

paragraphs.name: previewTitle
paragraphs.text: How to make your first video game

virtuals.snippet: The struggles and accomplishments of learning web development
virtuals.subtitle: The struggles and accomplishments of learning web development
virtuals.emailSnippet:
Disclaimer: I started learning JS after already having a solid foundation on Ruby and OOP concepts, and I also took the quick course in CodeCademy the day before to get acquainted with the new syntax, so in this sense we could say I had a headstart. ¶

Day 1 (24 hours of Javascript basics) ¶

Day one started by writing some rapid-fire exercises to use the new syntax just learned. In the morning I wrote 7 functions that are very basic programming exercises, such as reversing a string, outputting…

d4ac3dd2defe.title: I’m a boring programmer (and proud of it)

content.subtitle: I have a confession to make — I’m not a rock star programmer. Nor am I a hacker. I don’t know ninjutsu. Nobody has ever called me a wizard.

virtuals.snippet: I have a confession to make — I’m not a rock star programmer. Nor am I a hacker. I don’t know ninjutsu. Nobody has ever called me a wizard.
virtuals.subtitle: I have a confession to make — I’m not a rock star programmer. Nor am I a hacker. I don’t know ninjutsu. Nobody has ever called me a wizard.
virtuals.emailSnippet:
Still, I take pride in the fact that I’m a good, solid programmer. One who works hard at his craft and really enjoys it, even without the fancy labels. ¶

Yet every week I see a call for ninja programmers, who I assume slice lines of code with incredible precision. I read about tech rock stars, who I imagine write functions as beautiful as the “Stairway to Heaven” solo. I hear people throw around the word hacker (and the associated hack, hackfest, and hackathon) as if haphazardly chopping…

paragraphs.text: I’m a boring programmer (and proud of it)

1f126068f6d8.title: 5 Reasons Why You Should Build A Small Business — Not A Start-up

virtuals.subtitle: BY JON WESTENBERG
virtuals.emailSnippet:
I know we all want to do important things. We all want to work on important products, start important companies and accomplish tasks that could change the world and have an enormous impact. I see this in entrepreneurs and the tech community more than anywhere else. ¶

The question we ask, whenever we hear about a new business or idea, whether it’s renewable energy or a messaging app or a fucking hamster sled, is this: ¶

Will it scale?

paragraphs.name: 930c
paragraphs.text: 5 Reasons Why You Should Build A Small Business — Not A Start-up
